title: Jonah's Anger and God's Compassion
shortSummary: Jonah 4 reveals the prophet's displeasure and anger over God's mercy toward Nineveh, highlighting Jonah's struggle with God's grace extended to sinners. The chapter concludes with God teaching Jonah about compassion, emphasizing His sovereign care for all people, even those Jonah deemed unworthy.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - Prophet Jonah's mission to Nineveh

keyCharacters.name: Jonah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who is angry over God's mercy toward Nineveh and struggles to understand God's compassion.

keyCharacters.name: The LORD (God)
keyCharacters.description: The sovereign God who shows mercy to Nineveh and teaches Jonah about compassion through the gourd and the worm.

definitions.definition: Showing unmerited favor and kindness, especially by God toward sinners.
Compassionate and forgiving, withholding deserved punishment.
A strong, scorching wind from the east, symbolizing hardship or judgment.
A fast-growing plant used here as a shade to provide relief, symbolizing God's provision.

outline.heading: Jonah's Anger and Prayer
outline.description: Jonah expresses deep anger over God's mercy toward Nineveh and prays, revealing his struggle with God's gracious character and his desire for death rather than life under God's plan.

outline.heading: Jonah's Watch and the Gourd
outline.description: Jonah positions himself outside the city to observe its fate, and God provides a gourd to give him shade and comfort, demonstrating God's care for Jonah despite his anger.

outline.heading: The Withering of the Gourd and Jonah's Reaction
outline.description: God sends a worm to wither the gourd and a scorching wind, causing Jonah to faint and express a wish to die, highlighting his selfishness and misplaced priorities.

outline.heading: God's Lesson on Compassion
outline.description: God contrasts Jonah's pity for the gourd with His own compassion for Nineveh's many inhabitants, teaching Jonah about divine mercy and the value of human life.

application: Trust in God's sovereign mercy even when it challenges your personal expectations or desires.
Pray honestly about your frustrations but remain open to God's teaching and correction.
Cultivate compassion for others, recognizing that God's love extends to all people, regardless of their background.
Remember that God's plans are higher than ours and that His grace is meant to lead to repentance and salvation.

keyVerses.text: And he prayed unto the LORD, and said, I pray thee, O LORD, was not this my saying, when I was yet in my country? Therefore I fled before unto Tarshish: for I knew that thou art a gracious God, and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness, and repentest thee of the evil.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jonah's understanding of God's character and his internal conflict over God's mercy.

keyVerses.text: Then said the LORD, Doest thou well to be angry?
keyVerses.significance: God challenges Jonah's anger, prompting self-examination about righteous attitudes toward God's will.

keyVerses.text: And should not I spare Nineveh, that great city, wherein are more than sixscore thousand persons that cannot discern between their right hand and their left hand; and also much cattle?
keyVerses.significance: God emphasizes His compassion for the innocent and the value of life, underscoring His mercy toward repentant sinners.
